content: The agency I work for has agreed to sponsor the ticket for me to attend, so I'll be there :slight_smile:
cc @StPaulTim @jenlampton @Luke McCormick
Turns out that my work on the program committee makes me eligible for a free ticket to the virtual conference. This was not the case for an in person event. So, I am reconsidering participation.
Yay!!
Just reconsidering, not sure if I have time.
But, if we're doing anything for Backdrop that would be a factor.
Sooo. ... @Luke McCormick is attending, and so am I. Are you @jenlampton ?
...anyone else?
I am not.
Though I might attend Drupal Camp Asheville. https://www.drupalasheville.com/
No, I don't have a fancy company to buy my ticket :/
I'll wait 6 weeks and watch the sessions when they get posted online.
I might travel to DrupalEurope later this year in Barcelona, depends on my Drupal Commerce projects and Covid 19 of course. Will not attend the virtual one.

https://events.drupal.org/global2020/sessions/d7-d8-end-life%E2%80%94what-does-it-mean-what-are-my-options

D7 & D8 End of Life—What does it mean, what are my options?
Over a million websites rely on Drupal 7 & D8, and both reach the end of life (EOL) in 2022 (recently extended from 2021). Their popularity, combined with potentially difficult upgrade paths for D7 in particular, has site owners asking why this is happening, what it means for them, what they can do about it, and when they need to deal with all this.
Well, I think that that one will definitely be one that we all attend :sweat_smile:

...here's another one: https://events.drupal.org/global2020/sessions/discussion-bridging-gap-drupal-7-drupal-9

Discussion: Bridging the gap from Drupal 7 to Drupal 9
As of this session proposal, approximately 66% of Drupal sites are still on Drupal 7*. With Drupal 9 around the corner, and Drupal 7's end of life coming up in November of next year, it's critical to have as smooth an onramp as possible for people crossing the chasm.
Those certainly seem to be hot topics at this time.

I haven't gotten my free registration code. I may have asked too late and/or may get it late. So, I won't be there at start of DrupalCon, which is fine with me, but might join later if things come through.

I got plenty of work to focus on anyway.
I'm watching the Driesnote. Is anybody else?
...and just as I typed that, it ended.

I watched it :raised_hand: ...not sure how to feel about the future of Drupal ...some of the plans were exciting, some sounded scary and confusing for the average person :shrug: ...I couldn't help but feel that they are complicating things even more (architecturally speaking), and I kept feeling that it would take a degree in astrophysics and being an expert in string theory to be able to understand how things work :sweat_smile:
Isn't that what ambitious digital experiences are about?
@klonos I agree. I think that helps us understand our market. Much of Dries' talk today was about him wanting to claw back into the space where we already are.
Dries used a project technique that I love, which originated at Amazon: write the press release first! Then design a product that satisfies it.
Screen-Shot-2020-07-14-at-10.35.04-AM.png

I did not see it as that ...it felt more like a way to "groom" the data from the user survey into validating the initiatives he was "proposing" (in quotes, because I feel that they are actually being imposed). It felt totally hypocritical (with regards to what the community wants) ...on one hand you had Angie admit that most people/sites in D7 are hesitant to move to D8/9, and then Dries openly said that he excluded feedback from people that have not tried D8 :shrug:

@Luke McCormick am I to assume that you'll attend the "Why open source contribution is essential to your business" session that's next? ...I'm leaning towards "Drupal as a digital asset management system" that's at the same time.

I'm currently watching David Needham's config management session. (Where, btw, he namechecked @jenlampton near the beginning -- he credited her with showing him the 3-environment pattern)

I was planning to do DAM as well. Then "software architecture". Then there are multiple things, but I'll probably do Migrations, then Layout Builder, D8 front-end components, and then extending views.
DAM session is starting now. Islandora sounds interesting.
Yup I'm watching that now :slight_smile:
Well, I just did a lengthy plug for Backdrop in the post-event hangout at the nonprofit summit.
Folks from nonprofits lamenting how hard it is to do updates with composer seems like our target demographic.
Is anyone able to find out if higher-ed in general is still troubled about moving to D8/9?
The developers I know at the University of Minnesota seem happy with Drupal 8. That's very specific.
I know some from CA who are happy with it and some who are not and are wondering where they are going to go.
I've mostly moved past my dislike for composer, but the push towards decoupled and javascript frameworks that Drupal 10 seems to be going in has me worried

Hi, Steven DuBois. Welcome to the Backdrop CMS community on Zulip. I'm your friendly neighborhood Dragonbot. Try '@Dragonbot help' for a list of things I can help you with. There are lots of friendly humans that hang around here, so please feel free to ask questions.

Here is a short (3 min) video to help you navigate Zulip. https://youtu.be/DN8YL2MrsSU
Dries kept mentioning "javascript menu components" and I have no idea what he was talking about

I felt the same way @sdubois :disappointed: ...I was grabbing screenshots from the keynote, so for the benefit of others, the results of the community survey were "groomed" to produce this list of potential initiatives for D10:
Screen-Shot-2020-07-14-at-8.15.55-pm.png
...the simplified version of what the 1 star on any initiative meant is "endorsed by the community", by both novice and advanced users.
...2 stars meant is "strongly endorsed" by all users.
...so further into the presentation, the following 4 were selected as initiatives:
Screen-Shot-2020-07-14-at-8.30.08-pm.png
...so far, so good.
...then when time came for the final initiative to be selected out of the "runner-ups" in the list, this happened:
Screen-Shot-2020-07-14-at-8.30.21-pm.png
...so basically it was "nope, we're not gonna do what the community has clearly asked ....we'll do JS components instead"
Yeah, and it seemed like most people in the Hopin chat thought it was great!
:rolling_eyes:
and I still have no clue what he was talking about. What is a "javascript menu component" and why do people want that?
...I know what he was talking about, but you are proving my point: they will complicate things even more with D10 than what they've already done with D8/9 :shrug:
was he talking about Web Components?
...he was talking about adding both a ReactJS as well as a VueJS component in core, and then use those to produce things like menu components.

So my understanding of React and Vue is that they process data provided by things like JSON:API and GraphQL. So was Dries saying that Menus in Drupal 10 will be provided as JSON/GraphQL in addition to HTML?
...yay! ...making the menu system even harder to understand and/or work with for people that know php :rolling_eyes:
My understanding is correct?
Sorry @sdubois ...my knowledge of those 2 JS frameworks and JS in general is limited, so I don't understand how they are planning to do the final implementation :shrug:
Ok

...to me this bit of the keynote (selecting initiatives for D10) seemed like they (Dries? Acquia? ...I don't know) had already decided on those, and then they needed a way to present that these are what the community wants as well. ...so although the presentation may have started with the results of the survey, and ended in the selected initiatives, to me it seemed that a very smart marketing person actually went the other way: they had the set of initiatives to begin with, and their job was to go all the way back to the survey results, while on the way they "groomed" slides and made up reasons to convince the audience that the initiatives were a direct result of the survey. FAKE NEWS I say FAKE NEWS! :sweat_smile:

...things like "we excluded the results from everyone that has been using D7 and has not tried D8 yet" (which was not the question in the survey by the way) and "...although this (JS components) is not what the users have asked for, but we should do it anyway" (paraphrasing the last one) just do not seem right to me.

@klonos -- getting rough on the benevolent dictator! I think he has a certain amount of leeway to promote things he likes. But it does help clarify our market opportunity. There are a lot of people out there that want (and need) to create nice websites who don't have a strong opinion about things like "JavaScript Components." You definitely shouldn't have to know what those are (and how to use them well) to create a useful and attractive site.
@Luke McCormick nah, I'm not even trying to question the dictator's powers; just saying that the dictator was trying to use the survey to present the dictatorship as democracy is all :sweat_smile:

Regardless of how you feel about Drupal, one thing they do that we don't, that I've been drumming about forever, is document and maintain priorities. This speech gives a clear vision of where they want to go. We don't do that clearly enough. We should learn from them.
Agreed on that @docwilmot
I guess you need to be registered to see the driesnote?

@Herb - It's my understanding that all DrupalCon content will be restricted to DrupalCon participants/registrants until September, when it will be released on YouTube. There might be some exception made for the Driesnote, but I have not heard of it yet.

This is unfortunate, but I understand the need to provide some extra value to those who pay for tickets (to encourage folks to do so). I think an exception could be made for Driesnote and probably should be.
You can't gate the propaganda.
That's totally understandable. Maybe they could charge per video. I might pay

There's 2 clashing sessions I'd like to attend:

  • D7 & D8 End of Life—What does it mean, what are my options?
  • The Olivero theme: Turning a wild idea into core
    ...hard to choose :thinking:
I'm watching the end of life session
is this dude in his car?
I watched some of the Olivero theme session. Very interesting, and fills me with conflicting emotions. ("Oh, that's how you solve that kind of problem" AND "This is what's wrong with Drupal!")
